questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with high-grade fever, headache, and cervical lymphadenopathy for 2 days. He has now developed a rash that began on the face and later spread to the body. The rash evolved from macules to papules and then vesicles. He has a recent history of travel to Africa. What is the genetic material of the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The differential diagnoses for fever with maculopapulovesicular rash include:
    • Chickenpox (Varicella-zoster virus): The rash is centripetal, with lesions at different stages, and mild to absent lymphadenopathy.
    • Monkeypox: The rash starts on the face (centrifugal distribution), lesions evolve synchronously, and there is prominent lymphadenopathy.
  • The patient's travel to Africa and lymphadenopathy strongly point to monkeypox, caused by the Monkeypox virus.
  • Monkeypox virus:
    • Family: Poxviridae
    • Genus: Orthopoxvirus
    • Genome: Enveloped linear dsDNA virus
    • Unique feature: Replicates in cytoplasm (unlike most DNA viruses).

Explanation of Other Options:

ssRNA virus (Option A): Includes Paramyxoviridae (Measles, Mumps), Picornaviridae, Togaviridae (Chikungunya), Flaviviridae (Dengue, Zika). These can cause fever and rash but do not present with vesicles, and lymphadenopathy is not as prominent. Also, lesion progression (macule → papule → vesicle) is not typical of ssRNA viral infections.

ssDNA virus (Option B): Includes Parvoviridae (Parvovirus B19), which causes erythema infectiosum (slapped cheek rash), not vesicular rash with lymphadenopathy.

dsRNA virus (Option C): Includes Reoviridae (e.g., Rotavirus), which cause gastroenteritis, not vesicular rash.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the Monkeypox virus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A vaccine is available for monkeypox.

  • The JYNNEOS vaccine (also known as Imvamune or Imvanex), based on the Modified Vaccinia Ankara (MVA-BN) strain, was approved in 2019 and offers around 85% protection against monkeypox.
  • It is given as two subcutaneous doses of 0.5 ml, 4 weeks apart, with immunity developing about 2 weeks after the 2nd dose.

Explanation of Other Options:

Options B, C and D are true.

Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies (Option B): Poxviruses, including monkeypox, replicate in the cytoplasm and produce eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies (similar to vaccinia and smallpox).

Icosahedral symmetry (Option C): Poxviruses have a complex structure but are generally described as having icosahedral symmetry at the core level.

Enveloped virus (Option D): Monkeypox virus is a large enveloped dsDNA virus belonging to the Poxviridae family.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9534018/

questions.solution:
Explanation:

Monkeypox was declared a Health Emergency of International Concern on 23rd July 2022

questions.text: A 65-year-old male is admitted for elective surgery. Seventy-two hours after admission, he developed a urinary tract infection that was not present at the time of admission. Based on this scenario, which of the following is not part of the definition of a hospital-acquired infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Hospital-acquired infections (HAIs), also referred to as nosocomial infections, are defined based on timing and causation criteria:

  • The key requirement is that the infection must not be present or incubating at the time of hospital admission.
  • Symptoms typically appear ≥48 hours after admission, suggesting a hospital origin. (Option B ruled out)
  • The infection must occur in a patient admitted for reasons other than the infection itself. (Option C ruled out)
  • HAIs also include infections that become clinically apparent after discharge, as long as they were acquired during hospitalization (e.g., surgical site infections). (Option D ruled out)
  • Additionally, occupational infections (e.g., needlestick injuries in healthcare workers) and infections in newborns during passage through the birth canal are considered HAIs.

Reference:

Nosocomial Infections - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are false.
Assertion is false; reason is true.
Both assertion and reason are true, and reason does not explain assertion.
Both assertion and reason are true, and reason explains assertion.

questions.text:
Assertion: The majority of nosocomial infections are endogenous in origin, i.e., they involve the patient's own microbial flora, which may invade the body during surgical or instrumental manipulations.
Reason: Exogenous sources are from the hospital environment, healthcare workers (HCW), or patients.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The assertion is specifically about endogenous infections (from the patient's own flora), while the reason describes exogenous sources of infection. Although both statements describe sources of nosocomial infections, they refer to different causes (endogenous vs. exogenous).

Sources of infection in hospital-associated infections:

  • Endogenous sources are responsible for the majority of nosocomial infections. These are infections caused by the patient's own normal microbial flora, which may become pathogenic and invade sterile body sites following instrumentation, surgery, catheterization, or immunosuppression. For example:
    • Gut flora causing urinary tract infections after catheterization
    • Skin flora causing postoperative wound infections
  • Exogenous sources, as described in the reason, include:
    • Hospital environment: air, water, food, contaminated surfaces, and medical equipment (e.g. endoscopes, catheters, ventilators)
    • Healthcare workers (HCWs): who may carry and transmit pathogens such as Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) or Clostridioides difficile
    • Other patients in the hospital who may act as reservoirs for cross-infection

Reference:

Nosocomial Infections - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: Which of the following options correctly lists all of the ESKAPE pathogens responsible for hospital-associated infections?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ESKAPE pathogens are a group of highly virulent and drug-resistant organisms responsible for the majority of hospital-acquired infections, including catheter-associated UTIs, ventilator-associated pneumonia, bloodstream infections, and surgical site infections.

The acronym ESKAPE stands for:

  • E - Enterococcus faecium
  • S - Staphylococcus aureus
  • K - Klebsiella pneumoniae
  • A - Acinetobacter baumannii
  • P - Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • E - Enterobacter species

These organisms are known for their ability to "escape" the effects of antimicrobial drugs, hence the name. They are priority targets for infection control and antimicrobial stewardship due to their multidrug resistance and association with high morbidity and mortality in hospitalized patients.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4871955/

questions.text:
Standard precautions are a set of infection control practices used to prevent transmission of diseases that can be acquired by contact with blood, body fluids, non-intact skin (including rashes), and mucous membranes. These measures should be followed when providing care to or handling:
1. All individuals suspected to be of infectious disease
2. A patient who is not suspected of having an infectious disease
3. While handling blood specimens
4. While handling body fluids
5. While sterilizing any type of sharps or needles
Which of the above statements are true regarding the application of standard precautions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Standard precautions are a foundational component of infection prevention and control in healthcare settings. These measures are based on the principle that all patients and clinical specimens may potentially carry infectious agents, regardless of the presence or absence of symptoms. Therefore, standard precautions are universally applied and not limited to patients suspected of having an infection.

They apply to interactions involving:

  • All patients, whether symptomatic or not, as even asymptomatic individuals can transmit infections. (Statements 1 & 2 are true)
  • All blood and body fluids, including urine, feces, saliva, vomitus, and other secretions, which are considered potentially infectious. (Statements 3 & 4 are true)
  • All sharps and needles, which must be handled using strict safety protocols to prevent needlestick injuries and transmission of bloodborne pathogens. (Statement 5 is true)

Core elements of standard precautions include:

  • Hand hygiene (before and after patient contact)
  • Use of PPE (gloves, gowns, masks depending on exposure)
  • Safe injection and sharps handling
  • Environmental cleaning and disinfection
  • Respiratory hygiene and cough etiquette
  • Waste segregation and biomedical waste disposal 

Reference:

Standard Precautions for All Patient Care | Infection Control | CDC

questions.text:
The World Health Organization (WHO) has published standard guidelines describing when hand hygiene should be performed in healthcare settings, referred to as the "My Five Moments for Hand Hygiene". Based on these guidelines, which of the following scenarios require hand hygiene according to the "Five Moments" framework?
1. Before touching a patient
2. Before a clean/aseptic procedure
3. After body fluid exposure risk
4. After touching a patient
5. After touching patient's surroundings
After removing gloves
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The World Health Organization's (WHO) "My Five Moments for Hand Hygiene" defines five specific instances when healthcare workers should perform hand hygiene to minimize healthcare-associated infections (HAIs). These are:

  1. Before touching a patient
  2. Before clean/aseptic procedure
  3. After body fluid exposure risk
  4. After touching a patient
  5. After touching patient surroundings

While hand hygiene should also be performed after glove removal (scenario 6), this is not one of the five officially defined moments.

Reference:

WHO Guidelines on Hand Hygiene in Health Care First Global Patient Safety Challenge Clean Care is Safer Care

questions.text: Match the correct option with the layers of a mask as shown in the figure:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A standard surgical mask, shown in the image, has three distinct layers, each with specific material and function:

  1. Outer fluid repellent layer: Hydrophobic layer that can repel water, blood and body fluids.
  2. Middle filter layer: It is made up of melt-blown material; filters bacteria/viruses, and also filters out the water droplets. Unlike N95 respirators, the filter pore size of surgical masks is not standardized.
  3. Inner hydrophilic layer: Absorbs water, sweat and spit; made up of non-woven fabric.

When using a surgical mask, the following measures should be considered:

  • Shelf-life: Disposable (single-use); should be discarded or changed after 4-6 hours of use or earlier if it becomes soiled or wet.
  • Donning: Place the mask carefully, ensuring it covers the mouth and nose, adjust to the nose bridge, and tie it securely to minimize any gaps between the face and the mask.
  • Hanging mask syndrome: Masks should not be left dangling around the neck, a common practice observed among doctors, as doing so may contaminate the inner side of the mask.
  • Touching the front of the mask while wearing it should be avoided.
  • The mask should not be worn with a beard or an unshaven face.
  • Hand hygiene should be performed before donning the mask, upon touching or discarding a used mask.

Reference:

Layers of a standard surgical mask - ResearchGate

questions.text: Patients with similar infections requiring contact precautions can be placed together if single isolation rooms aren't available. This is called cohorting. What is the minimum distance required for spatial separation of two patients in such a setting?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Contact precautions are used to prevent the transmission of infectious agents that spread through direct or indirect contact with the patient or their environment.

Recommended Practices:

  • The ideal setting for patients requiring contact precautions is a single isolation room with an attached bathroom.
  • If a single room is unavailable, cohorting of patients infected or colonized with the same infectious organism is permissible.
  • When cohorting:
    • According to standard guidelines, a minimum spatial separation of 3 feet (approximately 1 meter) between patient beds is necessary to reduce the risk of cross-transmission of pathogens.
    • Ideally, a privacy curtain should also be used as a physical barrier between patients.

Additional infection prevention measures include:

  • Strict hand hygiene (soap/water or alcohol-based hand rub)
  • Use of PPE such as gloves and gowns
  • Single-use or dedicated patient equipment
  • Limited patient movement within healthcare settings
  • Regular cleaning and disinfection of patient care areas

Reference:

III. Precautions to Prevent Transmission of Infectious Agents | Infection Control | CDC

questions.text: A hospitalized patient was catheterized for 8 days. On the 8th day, the patient developed spikes of fever. A catheter-associated UTI is suspected, and a urine sample is sent for culture. The isolated organism grows profusely on MacConkey agar and ferments lactose, as shown in the image provided. Which of the following cellular features is most crucial for determining virulence and classifying this organism as a uropathogen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient presents with a catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CA-UTI), a common nosocomial infection. The culture shows a lactose-fermenting gram-negative rod growing on MacConkey agar, which is classic for Escherichia coli (E. coli).

Among the various virulence factors of uropathogenic E. coli (UPEC), the most crucial factor for pathogenicity in the urinary tract is the presence of fimbriae (especially type 1 and P fimbriae). These hair-like appendages mediate adhesion of the bacteria to uroepithelial receptors, facilitating colonization and infection even in the presence of urinary flow.

  • Type 1 fimbriae mediate attachment to the bladder epithelium.
  • P fimbriae bind to glycolipid receptors on renal tubular epithelial cells, allowing for ascending infections such as pyelonephritis.

Fimbriae are therefore essential in defining E. coli as a uropathogen, allowing persistence and pathogenicity in catheterized patients.

Explanation of Other Options:

Beta-lactamase (Option A) provide antibiotic resistance by hydrolyzing beta-lactam antibiotics. While this contributes to treatment failure, it is not a virulence factor or determinant of uropathogenicity.

Glycocalyx (slime layer) (Option B) aids in biofilm formation, especially on implanted devices, and is more relevant in staphylococci (e.g., Staph. epidermidis). While it may aid colonization, fimbriae are more specific for UPEC virulence.

Urease (Option C) breaks down urea into ammonia, raising urine pH, and promoting struvite stone formation. This is a key virulence factor of Proteus species, not E. coli.

choices.text: Increased lateral urethral pressure leading to impaired mucosal blood flow and mucin secretion

questions.text: A 45-year-old male was admitted following blunt abdominal trauma resulting in a confirmed urinary bladder rupture. He was managed with surgical repair of the bladder and an indwelling urinary catheter for drainage. On post-operative day 7, the patient develops fever, dysuria, and bacteriuria. Laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count and positive urine culture. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for the development of a urinary tract infection (UTI) in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient is presenting with catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI), a common healthcare-associated infection. Multiple mechanisms contribute to the development of UTI in catheterized patients:

  • Presence of the catheter itself: An indwelling urinary catheter acts as a foreign body, disrupting the normal defense mechanisms of the urinary tract. Bacteria can adhere to the catheter surface and form a biofilm, leading to ascending colonization and infection.
  • Incomplete emptying of the bladder: Catheters may cause residual urine Stagnant urine creates an ideal medium for bacterial growth, promoting infection. Incomplete drainage also prevents mechanical flushing of organisms.
  • Increased lateral urethral pressure leading to impaired mucosal blood flow and mucin secretion: Long-term catheter use or improper positioning can increase urethral wall pressure, which may impair blood flow and reduce mucin secretion. Mucins are glycoproteins that form part of the urothelial protective barrier, and their loss increases vulnerability to bacterial invasion.

These combined factors create an environment where uropathogens can thrive, leading to symptomatic UTI.

Reference:

Catheter-Associated Urinary Tract Infections: Current Challenges and Future Prospects - PMC

questions.text: Treatment of catheter-associated asymptomatic bacteriuria is recommended in all the following cases except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Catheter-associated asymptomatic bacteriuria (CA-aSB) refers to the presence of significant bacteriuria in catheterized patients without signs or symptoms of urinary tract infection.

Routine treatment of CA-aSB is not recommended unless specific high-risk conditions are present, because indiscriminate antibiotic use can lead to antimicrobial resistance and unnecessary side effects.

Treatment is recommended only in the following conditions:

  • Pregnancy: Asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnancy carries a high risk of pyelonephritis, preterm delivery, and low birth weight. (Option B ruled out)
  • Before urological procedures involving mucosal trauma (e.g., transurethral resection of the prostate - TURP), due to risk of bacteremia. (Option C ruled out)
  • Persistent bacteriuria >48 hours after catheter removal, as this may indicate early infection or colonization that could become symptomatic. (Option D ruled out)

In the given case (Option A), the bacteriuria persisted for only 24 hours after catheter removal, and the patient is asymptomatic. Since the indication is not met (i.e., <48 hours persistence), antibiotic treatment is not recommended.

Reference:

Asymptomatic Bacteriuria - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: A patient is scheduled for elective surgery. In order to prevent surgical wound infections, the surgical team follows standard infection control protocols. Which of the following practices should be avoided to minimize the risk of postoperative wound infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Shaving of hair should be avoided to minimize the risk of postoperative wound infection.

Prevention of surgical site infections (SSIs):

  • Preoperative bathing: Patients should bathe using plain soap or antimicrobial soap (e.g., chlorhexidine) before surgery to reduce skin microbial load, especially around the surgical site. (Option A ruled out)
  • Surgical antibiotic prophylaxis: Antibiotics should be administered ideally within 60 minutes before the surgical incision (up to 120 minutes for drugs like vancomycin or fluoroquinolones). This ensures effective serum and tissue concentrations at the time of microbial exposure. (Option B ruled out)
  • Hair removal: For patients undergoing any surgical procedure, hair removal should not be done or, if it is necessary, it should be removed only with a clipper. Shaving is strongly discouragedat all times.
  • Wound dressing: The surgical site should be dressed daily under aseptic precautions. Any discharge should be removed. Strict hand hygiene and the use of gloves must be followed at all times. (Option D ruled out)

Reference:

Evidence-Based Recommendations on Measures for the Prevention of Surgical Site Infection

questions.text: A microbiologist has cultured a specimen from throat infection.the results came out to be positive. Later she wants to discard the culture. How such waste is pre-treated and what is the concentration?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Infectious liquid waste generated in microbiology laboratories, such as positive cultures, must be disinfected prior to disposal to reduce the risk of contamination or infection.

  • The recommended chemical method involves 1-2% sodium hypochlorite (commercial bleach) with a contact time of approximately 30 minutes. This concentration is effective for routine disinfection of biohazardous liquids, such as microbial cultures, without causing excessive corrosion or fumes.
  • Higher concentrations (like 10%) are not recommended routinely due to their corrosive nature, increased health hazards, and environmental concerns.
  • Alternatively, autoclaving is an approved and effective method of sterilization, especially for solid culture media, used Petri dishes, or other microbiological waste.
  • After chemical or thermal pre-treatment, the waste should be disposed of via the designated biomedical waste streams, typically into yellow category containers as per national guidelines.

Explanation of Other Options:

Sodium hypochlorite - 10% (Option A): A 10% concentration is unnecessarily high, corrosive, and not recommended for routine laboratory waste. 1-;2% is sufficient and recommended.

NaCl - 7.5% (Option B): Sodium chloride has no disinfectant properties and is not used in waste decontamination.

Lysol - 5% (Option C): While Lysol (cresol-based) can be used for surface disinfection, it is not standard for liquid infectious waste pre-treatment. Also, standard concentration recommendations vary based on formulation.-

Reference:

https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/disinfection-sterilization/chemical-disinfectants.html

questions.text: A 30-year-old nurse is working in the intensive care unit and is involved in patient care. During her shift, she experiences several incidents involving potential exposure to infectious agents. She is concerned about the risk of infection from her occupational exposures. She comes to you for advice on which types of exposures are considered occupational and require post-exposure management. Which of the following is not considered an occupational exposure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Brief contact of infected fluid with intact skin (e.g., a few seconds) is not considered significant exposure, as intact skin acts as an effective barrier unless compromised or exposed for a prolonged duration.

Occupational exposures in healthcare settings refer to events where a healthcare worker (HCW) is exposed to infectious materials, particularly blood or body fluids, that may transmit blood-borne pathogens such as HIV, HBV, or HCV.

Occupational exposures include:

  • Percutaneous injuries, such as needle stick injuries or injuries with other contaminated sharps. (Option A ruled out)
  • Splash injuries involving mucous membranes (e.g., eyes, nose, mouth). (Option B ruled out)
  • Exposure to non-intact skin, including abraded, chapped, or eczematous skin, particularly when splashed with blood or body fluids. (Option C ruled out)
  • Prolonged contact with intact skin (e.g., exposure to infectious fluids for several minutes or more) may be considered occupational, especially if the volume of fluid is large.

Reference:

Management of occupational exposure to blood and body fluids in primary care - PMC

questions.text: A 32-year-old healthcare worker (HCW) sustains a needle-stick injury while drawing blood from a patient with unknown HIV status. What is the correct sequence of steps to manage the exposure and prevent blood-borne infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Post-exposure management of healthcare workers (HCWs) following needle-stick injury is a structured, time-sensitive protocol aimed at reducing the risk of transmission of blood-borne infections such as HIV, HBV, and HCV.

The correct stepwise approach is as follows:

  1. First aid: Immediately wash the wound with soap and running water. Avoid scrubbing or using harsh disinfectants like bleach or alcohol.
  2. Report to designated nodal center: All exposures must be promptly reported to a designated infection control or occupational health unit.
  3. Take first dose of PEP for HIV: Administer first dose of HIV PEP within 1-2 hours, ideally as early as possible (preferably within 2 hours, latest by 72 hours).
  4. Testing for blood-borne viruses: Simultaneous testing of both the HCW and the source patient for HIV, HBV, and HCV must be done, after obtaining consent.
  5. Initiate appropriate prophylaxis: Based on risk assessment, continue PEP for HIV (28-day regimen) and consider HBV vaccination or HBIG, depending on the vaccination status of the HCW and the source.

Further steps include documentation, counseling, informed consent, and scheduled follow-up testing (e.g., at 6 weeks, 3 months, and 6 months).

Reference:

Manual of Infection Prevention and Control in Healthcare Settings

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents to the emergency department with diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal cramps, suggestive of acute gastroenteritis. History reveals recent consumption of water from a nearby river with known fecal contamination. Public health officials collect a water sample for microbiological evaluation. Which of the following bacterial indicators would best confirm recent fecal contamination of the water source?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

Fecal streptococci, particularly species of Enterococcus, are considered reliable and specific indicators of recent fecal contamination, especially from human sources.

  • These organisms are more resistant to environmental stress and survive longer in aquatic environments than coli, helping to identify recent contamination events effectively.
  • Their presence in water sources is a red flag for fresh sewage or fecal pollution, prompting urgent public health action.
  • Enterococcus faecalis and Enterococcus faecium are commonly tested species in modern water quality assessment programs.

Explanation of Other Options:

Coliform (other than Escherichia coli) (Option A):

Coliforms are non-specific indicators and can originate from soil, vegetation, or environmental sources, not necessarily fecal. Thus, they do not confirm fecal origin conclusively.

Fecal (thermotolerant) Escherichia coli (Option B):

While E. coli confirms fecal pollution, it does not distinguish between recent and past contamination. It persists longer in water compared to fecal streptococci.

Clostridium perfringens (Option D):

This is a spore-forming anaerobe used to assess past or long-standing contamination. Spores are highly resistant and persist in the environment long after the contamination event.

questions.text: A public health officer is tasked with testing water samples from a community suspected of having fecal contamination. One of the tests performed involves detecting fecal E. coli in the water sample to confirm recent contamination. Which of the following methods is used for detecting fecal E. coli in the water?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Eijkman test is a differential coliform test used to determine whether coliform bacilli detected in a presumptive test are specifically Escherichia coli (fecal coliforms).

  • Principle: Based on the ability of coli to ferment lactose with acid and gas production at 44°C, a temperature tolerated by E. coli but not by most other coliforms.
  • Method: After a presumptive positive test (acid and gas production), subcultures are made into single-strength MacConkey medium and incubated at 44°C in thermostatically controlled water baths.
  • Interpretation: Gas production in Durham tubes after 24 hours confirms the presence of fecal coli. Further confirmation can be done with indole production and citrate utilization tests.
  • Quantification: The number of coli bacteria present is estimated using McCrady's probability tables.

Explanation of Other Options:

Membrane filtration method (Option B):

  • The membrane filtration methodis a widely used technique to detect fecal E. coli in water samples.
  • This method is based on the filtration of a known volume (eg. 100 mL) of water through a cellulose membrane of pore size 0.22-0.45 µm.
  • However, when asking specifically about detecting fecal E. coliin the context of stool or fecal contamination in water, the Eijkman test is a classical approach for initial detection.

Presence-absence test (Option C):

  • A qualitative screening test for detecting presence of coliforms or coli.
  • It is useful for rapid field screening but does not differentiate fecal from non-fecal coliforms, nor quantify the organisms.

Endotoxin detection test (Option D):

  • Detects endotoxins (lipopolysaccharide components)from Gram-negative bacteria, including coli, but it does not directly detect coli in samples.
  • It is more relevant for testing in medical and pharmaceutical contexts.

questions.text:
CDC recommends targeted air surveillance, which should be carried out for which of the following indications:
1) Investigation of an outbreak
2) For research purposes
3) Before fogging
4) After reconstruction or newly constructed buildings
5) After fogging
6) For short-term evaluation of a change in infection control practice
7) Routinely at regular intervals
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Routine air sampling (i.e. random or periodic sampling) is not recommended because

  • HAI rates are not related to levels of general microbial contamination of air or environmental surfaces,
  • There are no standard guidelines mentioning permissible levels of microbial contamination of environmental surfaces or air.

CDC recommends targeted air surveillance, which should be carried out for the following indications:

  1. Investigation of an outbreak (1) to identify airborne sources or contamination
  2. For research purposes (2), when scientific data on microbial burden is required
  3. After reconstruction or in newly constructed buildings (4), especially in critical care areas like ICUs and OTs, to ensure air safety
  4. After fogging or disinfection (5), to validate the effectiveness of environmental decontamination
  5. For short-term evaluation of a change in infection control practices (6), such as new HVAC systems or filtration protocols

Before fogging (3) is not a recommended indication, and routine surveillance (7) is explicitly discouraged due to a lack of correlation with infection outcomes and the absence of standard thresholds.

questions.text: What is the correct approach for an Antimicrobial Stewardship (AMS) team to frame a hospital's antimicrobial policy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Framing an effective antimicrobial policy is a core responsibility of the Antimicrobial Stewardship (AMS) team and must be done collaboratively and locally customized.

  • The AMS policy should not be a copy-paste document from another hospital or institute. Instead, it must reflect the local antimicrobial resistance (AMR) patterns and institution-specific practices. (Option D ruled out)
  • It should be based on standard national and international antimicrobial guidelines (e.g., WHO, ICMR) integrated with the hospital's local antibiogram.
  • After preparing the initial draft, the AMS team must consult with treating clinicians, microbiologists, pharmacists, and administrators to refine the policy. (Options A & B ruled out)
  • A common consensus ensures better acceptability and adherence, making the policy both practical and effective.
  • The policy is usually compiled as a syndrome-wise or system-wise pocketbook, outlining drug choices, dosages, and durations for easy clinical use.

Hospitals are also encouraged to periodically revise the policy based on updated resistance trends and emerging pathogens.

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK572068/

questions.text: In healthcare workers, following an occupational exposure (e.g., needlestick injury), what is the correct descending order of risk of transmission for the following bloodborne viruses?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The risk of bloodborne virus transmission in healthcare workers after percutaneous exposure (e.g., needlestick injury) differs for each virus, primarily based on infectivity, viral load, and environmental stability.

Transmission risk per exposure is highest for HBV, followed by HCV, and lowest for HIV.
